name: Lost and found
description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

key_work.title: Alice Guy-Blaché
key_work.brief_description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio. She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

constellations_primary.name: Lost and found
constellations_primary.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

start.title: Something Pacific
start.brief_description: Nam June Paik’s Something Pacific (1986) is made up of TVs buried in the grass outside and an interactive video wall within the building at the University of Southern California San Diego’s Media Center and is part of the Stuart Collection.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

end.title: Wanted!: Monty Mole
end.brief_description: Wanted: Monty Mole is a platform videogame that was published in 1984. The player controls the titular mole who has to travel around a coal mine collecting pieces of coal and other miscellaneous objects while avoiding various nasties and the infamous crushers.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Videogames can also become obsolete when consoles and systems age. Online emulators are often used to save games but this process decontextualises them, sometimes separating them from their initial meaning, like Wanted! Monty Mole (1984), which was a response to a mining strike.

start.title: Alice Guy-Blaché

She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

end.title: The Cabbage-Patch Fairy
end.brief_description: La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage-Patch Fairy) is considered the first fictional film with a scripted narrative. It was created by trailblazing French filmmaker Alice Guy-Blaché, who returned to the story numerous time early in her career.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage-Patch Fairy).

start.title: The Cabbage-Patch Fairy
start.brief_description: La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage-Patch Fairy) is considered the first fictional film with a scripted narrative. It was created by trailblazing French filmmaker Alice Guy-Blaché, who returned to the story numerous time early in her career.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

end.title: Welcome to Television (1956)
end.brief_description: Gyngell is often credited as being the first person to appear on Australian television on 16 September 1956, when he spoke the words, ‘Good evening, and welcome to television’.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Some think The Cabbage-Patch Fairy is a lost film, but it’s so similar to Guy Blaché’s later works, others believe it never existed. If it did, and later films are remakes, it’s like Bruce Gyngell’s Welcome to Television, which wasn’t recorded and was remade a year later.

start.title: Welcome to Television (1956)
start.brief_description: Gyngell is often credited as being the first person to appear on Australian television on 16 September 1956, when he spoke the words, ‘Good evening, and welcome to television’.

constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

end.title: Doctor Who
end.brief_description: The adventures of a Time Lord — a time-travelling humanoid alien known as the Doctor — who explores the universe in his TARDIS, a sentient time-travelling space ship. Along with a succession of companions, the Doctor saves civilisations, helps ordinary people and rights wrongs.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Much of early TV is lost because it was live. Taped TV content has also disappeared because videotape was expensive and reused whenever possible. Many early Doctor Who episodes are missing, though audio survives due to home viewers making recordings.

start.title: Doctor Who
start.brief_description: The adventures of a Time Lord — a time-travelling humanoid alien known as the Doctor — who explores the universe in his TARDIS, a sentient time-travelling space ship. Along with a succession of companions, the Doctor saves civilisations, helps ordinary people and rights wrongs.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

end.title: Match de Prestidigitation
end.brief_description: A magician divides himself into two people, who then perform tricks before transforming back into one person, in one of Georges Méliès’ early trick films that pioneered special effects.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Economic issues also led to the loss of more than 200 of Georges Méliès’ films, which were burnt to produce materials for boot heels during WWI. However, his missing films keep being discovered, like Match de Prestidigitation (1904) in 2016.

start.title: Match de Prestidigitation
start.brief_description: A magician divides himself into two people, who then perform tricks before transforming back into one person, in one of Georges Méliès’ early trick films that pioneered special effects.

constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

end.title: Something Pacific
end.brief_description: Nam June Paik’s Something Pacific (1986) is made up of TVs buried in the grass outside and an interactive video wall within the building at the University of Southern California San Diego’s Media Center and is part of the Stuart Collection.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Nam June Paik’s Something Pacific has been deliberately erased and renewed over time. It features TVs buried outside in grass and an interactive video wall inside, with the video wall periodically renovated and updated with new technologies while the artefacts outside decay.

start.title: Wanted!: Monty Mole
start.brief_description: Wanted: Monty Mole is a platform videogame that was published in 1984. The player controls the titular mole who has to travel around a coal mine collecting pieces of coal and other miscellaneous objects while avoiding various nasties and the infamous crushers.

end.title: The Missing Picture
end.creator_credit: Catherine Dussart, CNC and Rithy Panh
end.brief_description: Rithy Panh uses clay figures, archival footage and his narration to recreate the atrocities Cambodia’s Khmer Rouge committed between 1975 and 1979 in an attempt to reclaim Cambodian culture.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

constellations_other.name: Bophana: cultural memory on film
constellations_other.description: Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center is dedicated to the collection, preservation and presentation of audiovisual material related to Cambodia. Their collection includes archival footage, newsreels, documentaries, feature films, photographs and vinyl records.

links.description: Rithy Panh’s The Missing Picture tries to create context and history – the missing visual evidence – of both Cambodia’s culturally rich past and the Khmer Rouge’s violence. He uses a range of techniques to render what was lost including clay figures and dioramas.

start.title: Alice Guy-Blaché
start.brief_description: Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter, and the co-founder and artistic director of her own film studio. She made hundreds of films between during her career, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux

constellations_primary.name: Lost and found

end.title: Consequences of Feminism
end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: In Alice Guy-Blaché’s gender-flipping 1906 comedy, Les Résultats du féminisme (The Consequences of Feminism), men are relegated to raising kids, ironing and sewing while women smoke, drink and prey upon the ‘weaker sex’ with lurid advances.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

links.description: Alice Guy Blaché’s gender-swap silent comedy Les Résultats du féminisme reveals how women filmmakers have been critiquing gender roles and expectations since the beginning of cinema. While an original print may be hard to find, it’s available on YouTube.
